Introduction & Fundamentals.title: Introduction & Fundamentals
Introduction & Fundamentals.description: This chapter introduces the world of web development, how the internet works, and the foundations required to build modern websites.

details: Web development is the process of building websites and web applications.
It consists of frontend (UI), backend (logic), and full-stack development.
Web browsers display content using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.
The web uses a client-server model.
Browsers send requests to servers using HTTP or HTTPS.
Servers respond with web pages, data, or media.
Frontend deals with UI—HTML, CSS, JS, React.
Backend handles APIs, databases, authentication—Node.js, Express, MongoDB.
JavaScript manipulates the DOM to update UI dynamically.
VS Code, Git & GitHub, Chrome DevTools, Node.js, npm/yarn.
Understanding these tools increases developer productivity.

sections.summary: You now understand how the web works, differences between frontend and backend, and essential development tools.

HTML Basics.title: HTML Basics
HTML Basics.description: HTML defines the structure of a webpage using elements, attributes, and semantic markup.

details: The <head> contains metadata, title, and linking CSS.
HTML is made of nested elements.
Attributes add information such as id, class, src, alt.
Radio buttons, checkboxes, drop-downs, submit buttons.
Forms are essential for login, signup, search.
Always use alt text for images.

sections.summary: HTML is the foundation of every webpage and defines the structure of your content.

CSS Fundamentals.title: CSS Fundamentals
CSS Fundamentals.description: CSS controls the appearance of HTML content including layout, colors, typography, animations, and responsive design.

details: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.
It defines style rules for HTML elements.
Styles cascade based on specificity and order.
Every element is a box with margin, border, padding, and content.
Understanding the box model is essential for layout design.
Use responsive units for scalable UIs.

sections.summary: CSS transforms plain HTML into beautiful, responsive, and engaging user interfaces.

JavaScript Essentials.title: JavaScript Essentials
JavaScript Essentials.description: JavaScript enables interactivity, dynamic UI updates, and complex application logic.

details: JavaScript is the programming language of the browser.
It powers dynamic pages, real-time updates, and modern web apps.
Primitive: string, number, boolean, null, undefined.
Array loops: forEach, map, filter, reduce.

sections.summary: JavaScript powers interactivity and dynamic behavior in every modern website and web application.

DOM Manipulation.title: DOM Manipulation
DOM Manipulation.description: DOM Manipulation allows JavaScript to dynamically update the HTML structure, content, and styling of a webpage.

details: The DOM is a tree-like structure representing all elements on a webpage.
Every HTML tag becomes a JavaScript-accessible object.
JavaScript can modify content, styling, structure, and respond to user actions.
querySelector and querySelectorAll are modern selectors.
getElementById, getElementsByClassName, and getElementsByTagName are older but still useful.
innerHTML replaces full HTML content — use carefully.
classList.add(), remove(), and toggle() apply CSS classes cleanly.
Use document.createElement() to make new elements.
appendChild() or append() insert elements into the DOM.
addEventListener handles click, input, submit, keydown, etc.
Event listeners create interactive UI behavior.
Events travel from parent → child (capturing) or child → parent (bubbling).
e.preventDefault() prevents page reload on form submit.
Properties like checked, value, and placeholder modify behavior.
parentElement, children, nextElementSibling, previousElementSibling allow navigation in the DOM tree.
cloneNode(true) duplicates elements with child nodes.
Useful for card systems, chat messages, todo lists.
DOM updates dynamically show content such as posts, products, or results.
Avoid frequent DOM queries; store references.
Avoid unsafe innerHTML to prevent XSS.

sections.summary: By mastering DOM manipulation, you can build dynamic, interactive websites and understand how modern frameworks work internally.

Responsive Web Design.title: Responsive Web Design
Responsive Web Design.description: Responsive Web Design ensures web pages adjust beautifully across all screens—mobile, tablet, laptop, and desktop.

details: RWD allows layouts to adapt to different screen sizes.
Uses fluid layouts, flexible images, and CSS media queries.
Eliminates need for separate mobile and desktop sites.
Start with mobile layout as the base.
Add desktop styling using min-width breakpoints.
Results in cleaner code and better performance.
Ensures website scales properly on mobile devices.

units.%: Defines width based on parent element.
units.clamp(): Allows min, ideal, and max scaling values.

5. Media Queries.definition: CSS rules that apply at specific screen sizes.

details: Use rem and em instead of px.
Typography should scale smoothly across devices.
Flexbox handles automatic resizing and alignment.
flex-wrap wraps elements on smaller screens.
auto-fit and minmax() create responsive card layouts.
srcset and sizes load correct images for each device.
Use horizontal navbars on larger screens.

sections.summary: Responsive design ensures a consistent and usable experience on all devices.

React.js Fundamentals.title: React.js Fundamentals
React.js Fundamentals.description: React is a JavaScript library for building fast, scalable, component-based user interfaces.

details: Uses components to create reusable UI blocks.
Uses a virtual DOM for fast updates.
Components return JSX—HTML-like syntax in JS.
Components can be reused across pages.
Props pass data from parent to child.
Useful for toggles, modals, counters, inputs.
Runs side effects such as fetching data.
Every list item needs a unique key.
Use &&, ? :, and if statements to show/hide content.
Controlled components use state to track input values.

sections.summary: React enables modular UI creation, predictable rendering, and scalable frontend architectures.

Node.js Basics.title: Node.js Basics
Node.js Basics.description: Node.js allows JavaScript to run on the server and powers modern backend development.

details: Node.js is a runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine.
Uses non-blocking I/O and an event-driven model.
Express.js is the most popular Node framework.
A basic API includes routes, controllers, and middleware.
3. Creating a Server.example: const express = require('express'); const app = express(); app.listen(5000);

details: Functions that modify request/response before reaching routes.
Routes handle API endpoints and responses.
Used for database URLs, JWT secrets, API keys.

sections.summary: Node.js powers scalable servers and APIs using JavaScript on the backend.

REST APIs.title: REST APIs
REST APIs.description: REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for designing scalable and stateless web services using HTTP.

details: API stands for Application Programming Interface.
It allows two applications to communicate with each other.
Web APIs enable the frontend and backend to exchange data using JSON.
A set of rules for building scalable web services.
Uses stateless communication — each request is independent.
Uses HTTP methods like GET, POST, PUT, DELETE.
Endpoints represent URLs for API actions.
Frontend sends a request to backend.
Query params filter data; URL params identify a resource.
APIs commonly exchange data in JSON format.
Easy to read and compatible with JavaScript.
Used when results are too large to send at once.
Browsers restrict requests between different domains.

sections.summary: REST APIs allow communication between frontend and backend using HTTP methods and JSON. They form the core of modern web applications.

Authentication & Security.title: Authentication & Security
Authentication & Security.description: Authentication verifies user identity, while security protects applications from attacks. This chapter teaches secure login systems and API protection methods.

details: Authentication verifies who the user is.
Common login methods: email/password, OAuth, biometrics.
Authorization determines what the user can access.
Passwords should never be stored in plain text.
Hashing adds salt to prevent reverse engineering.
Contains encoded user ID and expiration time.
Access token: short-lived, used for API requests.
Refresh token: long-lived, used to generate new access tokens.
Login with Google, GitHub, Facebook, etc.
Tokens are verified with the provider.
Reduces user friction and increases security.
Middleware verifies JWT before allowing access.
Ensures only authenticated users can access sensitive routes.

7. Common Security Threats.CSRF: Cross-Site Request Forgery — forcing user actions.

details: Helmet adds security headers in Express apps.
Useful for login and API endpoints.

sections.summary: A secure application protects user data through authentication, hashing, token systems, and security best practices.

Databases for Web Apps.title: Databases for Web Apps
Databases for Web Apps.description: Databases store and manage application data. This chapter explains SQL, NoSQL, MongoDB, Mongoose, indexing, schema design, and real-world data structures.

details: A database stores structured or unstructured data for applications.
Web apps use databases to store users, posts, products, orders, etc.
Databases can be cloud-based or local.
SQL uses tables, rows, and schemas.
NoSQL uses documents, collections, and flexible structures.
SQL is good for relational data; NoSQL is good for rapid development.
MongoDB stores data in JSON-like documents.
Mongoose adds schema and validation to MongoDB.
Use schemas to define required fields and data types.
5. Mongoose Models.example: const UserSchema = new mongoose.Schema({ name: String });

details: Reference: store ObjectId of related document.
Enable IP whitelisting for cloud DBs.
Never store passwords in plain text.

examples: Auth system: store user email & hashed password.
Social media: posts, likes, comments, followers.

sections.summary: Databases allow web applications to persist and query structured information efficiently and securely.

Deployment & Hosting.title: Deployment & Hosting
Deployment & Hosting.description: Deployment is the process of publishing your website or web app to the internet using cloud platforms, hosting services, and deployment tools.

details: Deployment makes your web app accessible online.
Frontend and backend require different hosting approaches.
Modern deployment is cloud-based and automated.

options: Netlify — simple & fast for static sites.
GitHub Pages — hosts static sites for free.
Heroku — easy deployments (legacy free plan ended).

details: Used for API keys, DB URIs, JWT secrets.
Use .env files locally and cloud env settings online.
Frontend calls backend using the deployed URL.
React apps require npm run build before deployment.
The build folder contains optimized HTML, CSS, and JS.
Cloud hosts serve the static build files.
GitHub Actions & Vercel automatically deploy on push.

sections.summary: Deployment allows your web application to be used globally by hosting it on cloud platforms with secure, scalable configuration.
